input_text.Prompt:
By Lee Min-hyung

LG Uplus, the nation's third-largest mobile carrier, has invested $2 million in U.S.-based social robot maker JIBO.

The move is expected to boost the company's efforts to lead the information and technology market in the era of the Internet of Things (IoT).

"We have built a partnership with JIBO, aiming to leap to the world's No. 1 IoT-based company by 2020," an LG Uplus spokesman said Thursday.

The company said the JIBO ― the world's first social robot with artificial intelligence ― will be commercialized in the United States early next year.

IT startup JIBO, founded in January, plans to tap into Asian markets including Korea, China and Japan. JIBO has six special features enabling users to send messages to families and use video call services.

LG Uplus said the recent partnership deal is part of the company's "New Life Creator" vision.

"The vision is our effort to create customer-oriented values," the spokesman said. "In the past, suppliers were at the center of values, but it has shifted to customers. We will do our best to grow into a company creating 'values for life.'"

Generate a summary:
input_text.Response A: LG Uplus invested $2 million in JIBO, a U.S.-based social robot maker, to become the world's No.1 IoT based company by 2020. JIBO, the world's first social robot with artificial intelligence, has six special features enabling users to send messages to families and use video call services. LG Uplus said the recent partnership deal is part of the company's "New Life Creator" vision.
input_text.Response B: LG Uplus, South Korea's third-largest mobile carrier, has invested $2m in US-based social robot maker JIBO, which plans to tap into Asian markets, including Korea, China and Japan. The partnership is expected to help LG Uplus lead the information and technology market in the era of the Internet of Things (IoT). "We have built a partnership with JIBO, aiming to leap to the world's No. 1 IoT-based company by 2020," an LG Uplus spokesman said. The company added that the JIBO, which was developed in January, would be commercialised in the US early next year.

label_annotations.feedback: Response A incorrectly words the summary to imply that the acquisition will make the buyer the leader in IoT, which is not the case. There is also a lot of useful information missing. Response B much more accurately gleans the main points from the article and structures them well.
